Name: NOVA: Race from the Sun 5th Player Expansion
Description:
The 5th Player Expansion for NOVA: Race from the Sun includes everything necessary for a 5th player including 20 additional Tech Cards, 15 dice in 8 colors, a player mat, a spaceship player marker, a Crew Population figure, a Hack token and a deluxe dice bag.

-description from designer

Name: Warfare on Distant Planets
Description:
Warfare on Distant Planets is a set of rules for science fiction battles with 6mm figures.

Humanity has spread to the stars and they are not alone now they battle with various other races to control distant as of yet unnamed planets.

The rules have a random army choice system that ensures that games are not always evenly matched sometimes winning just means doing as much damage as possible before your troops are defeated.

Stats are given for a number of different forces and it would be easy to create your own as well.

Name: Card Bard
Description:
Card Bard is a two player card game in which each player takes the role of the magical traveling storyteller of old — The Bard.

A player’s deck represents their repertoire of ballads, stories, techniques, tricks, magical items, fantastical lore, and enchanting melodies that you will use to battle your opponent to win the hearts – and purses – of the folk of the land.

During the game, players use their cards to perform Songs and collect Fame. The game ends when a player accumulates 15 Fame and has no currently active Songs. That player wins the game.

Card Bard plays over a series of alternating turns that are made up of 4 steps. Each of these steps takes place every turn, even if nothing happens during the step.

1. Play: Use your available Actions to play or draw cards, and activate effects.

2. Resolve: Resolve all effects still in play then check for the win condition.

3. Recover: Recharge Actions, discard any unwanted and cards over the hand limit.

4. Draw: Draw back up to the hand limit.

While Card Bard can be played with the pre-constructed decks, much of the depth comes when players construct original decks. Each deck must contain exactly 31 cards, including their Bard and no more than three copies of any card, by name. Within these guidelines, any combination of song and composition cards can be used. The Bard card is a special card that your deck revolves around. Bards determine what types of cards you can play. All cards in your deck must either match your Bard’s instrumental mastery type or be of a neutral type. Bards also have special effects that can be used by paying the costs associated with them, listed on the card.

-description from designer

Name: Vampire: The Eternal Struggle – Promo Pack 2
Description:
Promotional pack for organised play
Contents are detailed below. The number before each card is the number of copies of that card in the bundle.

10 Benedito, a Lanterna
10 Bituin
10 Casey Snyder
10 Jacques Rouge
10 Leumeah
1 Una
1 The Ankara Citadel, Turkey
1 Black Metamorphosis
1 Murmur of the False Will
1 Parity Shift
1 Pentex Subversion

Name: Player's Play
Description:
Player's Play is a card game in which players can choose to participate ("play") each round or not, and the number of players that participate will determine what type of game is played.

Each player is dealt a hand of 5 cards, and 4 participation cubes. Two cards form the deck are turned face up and will determine the trump suits for the game. In turn order, the players decide if they wish to participate, spending a participation cube if they choose to do so.

If one player participates, it will be a solitaire game.  If two players participate, it is a blackjack style game.  If three players participate, it is a poker style game.  If four participate, it is a trick-taking game.  If a player wins one of these mini-games, they receive a victory point, and the first person to three victory points wins.

Name: White Star Wizard
Description:
Pad Pad games are board games on small pads (1/3 A4). The board and the rules are on every sheet and everyone gets a sheet. The pad and a pencil is all that is needed. No big board to lay out, no fiddly pieces, easy to carry and simple rules, so the games can be played almost anywhere; on a ferry, train, waiting room, tent etc.

Story; You are a powerful Elemental Wizard. To prove you are the best, you have challenged your friends to a friendly competition. Try to outsmart the other wizards and become a White Star Wizard.

Each player is a wizard casting Elemental spells, trying to score the most victories before all Elements have been conquered.

Name: Refighting History: Volume 8 – The Seven Years War Western Theatre: Small Actions
Description:
Looking at the Seven Years War, military historians tend to concentrate on the big battles. However, the day to day campaign activity of the combatants included reconnaissance, raids, probing actions, resupply and a host of other minor operations that frequently lead to small skirmishes.

What I want to do in this volume of Refighting History is to take some of these actions, however small, and however sketchy in terms of accounts, and turn them into wargames. They will also demonstrate that you do not need large armies to wargame the Seven Years War.
The Western Theatre accounts provide details of the day to day activity by both armies. Coupled with this, the great variety of light and irregular troops provides a whole range of different unit.

The result is this volume with nine small historical actions refought on the wargame table. There is also a significant amount of background on the units involved coupled with art work to illustrate the uniforms.

—description from designer

The scenarios are compatible with many rulesets although Sharp Practice ! is recommended by the author (who uses his own modifications of his set The War Game Rules).

Name: Refighting History: Volume 1 – Seven Years War: Fighting Withdrawals
Description:
Refighting History is a series of wargame books by Charles S Grant. In this series Charles describes historical actions, provides the detail of the forces involved and the preparation to bring the actions to the wargame table. Each refight is then described both in words and pictures. These will include not only famous larger battles but also smaller actions which can be achieved with modest wargame forces.

In addition to the battles (Asch, Hoyerswarda, Pretsch) and games Charles includes sections on tactics, troop types and the development of his own armies.

The series aim to bring research, real scenarios , lots of pictures and the fun of wargaming to the reader.

—description from publisher

Name: Refighting History: Volume 2 – The War of the Austrian Succession: Mollwitz, Chotusitz and Sahay
Description:
Having covered some relatively small actions in Volume 1 of Refighting History Volume 2 examines some larger battles. The battles in question come from the War of the Austrian Succession and more specifically the First Silesian War.

The first battle is something of a wargame classic - Mollwitz. The Grant’s first Mollwitz wargame is coved with an excerpt from The War Game describing how it was first fought back in 1968. The battle is then revisited and with quite different results. There is then “A slice of Mollwitz” looking at only one particular part of the same battle.

The second battle, Chotusitz, is rather less well known and took place the year after Mollwitz. The battle includes an unusual twist but you will have to read it to discover what it is.

The third battle is the rather obscure battle of Sahay. This battle required quite a lot of detective work and no small amount of conjecture. The end result is a most interesting action.

In addition to the battles there is an update on Charles’ wargame armies and a section on battlefield manoeuvre in the mid eighteenth and its implications for wargaming.
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: Ruas Perigosas: Expansion for Zurvivors
Description: Dangerous Streets: Expansion for Zurvivors is a Card Game that will offer new experiences with the Zurvivors base game, with new survivors, expanding the city with establishments, challenges and obstacles, making the game even more exciting!

Name: For Motherland! The Russian Front, 1941-44
Description:
For Motherland! The Russian Front, 1941-44 is the single map game design by renowned Japanese game designer, Masahiro Yamazaki. This edition features a mounted map and delivers an eminently-playable version of his original, two-map War for the Motherland release that can be played to completion in a single sitting.

The game begins with Operation Barbarossa marking the German invasion of the Soviet Union, and culminates towards the end of the war when the Russians had effectively driven back the German forces and were entering the final stages of the epic struggle on the Eastern Front when the tide had completely turned. The game includes four variable turn scenarios: 

     Operation Barbarossa (1 to 7 Game-Turns),
     The Road to Stalingrad (1 to 12 Game-Turns),
     Fall Blau (8 to 17 Game-Turns), and
     War for the Motherland campaign (1 to 22 Game-Turns). 


One of the nice new twists implemented for the strength chit system is the variable and increasing combat chit strength for the Soviets over time to model the increasing combat effectiveness of the Soviet Armies.

Product Information:
    Complexity: 5 out of 10
    Solitaire Suitability: 7 out of 10 (no hidden units)
    Time Scale: 1 or 2 months per turn
    Map Scale: 74 km per hex
    Unit Scale: Army (Soviets, Axis Minors) and Corps (German)
    Players: one to two, best with two
    Playing Time: 2-5 hours for scenarios, 8+ hours for campaign

-description from publisher's website

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Gathering Storm I – Fall of Cadia
Description:
Gathering Storm: Fall of Cadia is a campaign supplement for the Seventh Edition of Warhammer 40,000. It is a 1st part of the Gathering Storm series.

For ten thousand years Cadia has stood firm against the horrors spewed forth by the Eye of Terror. There are no records of how many valiant souls have fallen defending the fortress worlds of the Cadian Gate — but by their sacrifice, the tide of horror stemmed. But there is no sacrifice big enough to stop what is coming.

Abaddon has unleashed the full might of his thirteenth Black Crusade and little hope remains. On Cadia itself, Ursarkar Creed and manifold Imperial forces mount a desperate defence, and they are soon to be joined by the strangest and most powerful of allies. Their arrival spurs a chain of events that will change things forever – the pylons will fall, the Eye will open, and a storm will come.

Full rules for fielding Saint Celestine, Belisarius Cawl and Inquisitor Greyfax with any army of the Imperium:

Saint Celestine confers Act of Faith on nearby units
Belisarius Cawl confers the Canticles of the Omnissiah on nearby units

Inquisitor Greyfax brings 6 new Inquisition Tactical Objectives

The Triumvirate of the Imperium – a formation bringing these three characters together;

6 new Ecclesiarchy Relics and 6 Arcana Mechanicum, usable by Adepta Sororitas and Cult Mechanicus forces;

The Grand Convocation and Imperial Crusade detachments – combine Cult Mechanicus,Skitarii and Mechanicus Knights in one army, and Black Templars and Adepta Sororitas in another;

Battlezone: Empyric Storms – rules for raging Warp Storm effects, some of which can be quite drastic: potentially removing invulnerable saves, or halving the effective range of psychic powers...

4 new Echoes of War missions.

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition): Chapter Approved – 2003 Edition
Description:
A series of three expansion books for Warhammer 40,000 third edition. Like the Book of the Astronomican for Rogue Trader, this short-lived annual collected articles from White Dwarf featuring various new rules, updates to the game, and army lists - some official, others merely experimental. There is substantial overlap between the volumes as each subsequent one was in part meant to update and/or collect much of the material of the previous.

The original in the series, Chapter Approved, was published in 2001, with Chapter Approved 2003 following in 2002 and Chapter Approved 2004 in 2003 (the year in the title indicating the coming year rather than when it was published). They were also known as the Second, Third, and Fourth Book of the Astronomican, respectively, in homage to the original from Rogue Trader.



Army Lists
- Feral Orks for use with the Codex: Orks
- Gaunt's Ghosts for use with the Codex: Imperial Guard (3rd Edition, 1st Codex)
- Armageddon Imperial Guard Regiments for use with the Codex: Imperial Guard (3rd Edition, 1st Codex)
- City Fight Imperial Guard for use with the Codex: Imperial Guard (3rd Edition, 1st Codex)
- Kroot Mercenaries
- Tyranid Seeding SwarmsAdditional Rules
- Trial Assault Rules
- Minor Psyker Powers
- Deathwatch Space Marines
- Transport Vehicles
- The Emperor's Champion

Scenarios
- Cityfight Subplots

Codex Updates
- Reprint updates for Space Marines, Armageddon, Orks, Blood Angels, Catachans, Eldar & Craftworld Eldar
- Revisions for Dark Eldar and Dark Angels

Playing and Painting
- Tactica: Cityfight
- 'Eavy Metal Showcase
- Tau Colour Schemes
- Painting Chaos Space Marines

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition): Chapter Approved – 2004 Edition
Description:
A series of three expansion books for Warhammer 40,000 third edition. Like the Book of the Astronomican for Rogue Trader, this short-lived annual collected articles from White Dwarf featuring various new rules, updates to the game, and army lists - some official, others merely experimental. There is substantial overlap between the volumes as each subsequent one was in part meant to update and/or collect much of the material of the previous.

The original in the series, Chapter Approved, was published in 2001, with Chapter Approved 2003 following in 2002 and Chapter Approved 2004 in 2003 (the year in the title indicating the coming year rather than when it was published). They were also known as the Second, Third, and Fourth Book of the Astronomican, respectively, in homage to the original from Rogue Trader.


Army Lists
- The Cursed Founding for use with Codex: Space Marines
- Feral Orks for use with the Codex: Orks
- Imperial Guard Armoured Company
- Kroot Mercenaries
- Tyranid Seeding Swarms
- Tau Rail Rifle for use with Codex: Tau
- Mounted Daemonettes for use with Codex: Chaos Space Marines (3rd Edition, 2nd Codex)

Miscellaneous Rules
- Transport Vehicles
- Vehicle Design Rules
- Tyranid Monstrosities

Scenarios
- Pitched Battle Mission
- Escalating Engagement Mission

Codex Updates
- Codex: Space Marines
- Codex: Armageddon
- Codex: Orks
- Codex: Blood Angels & Codex: Catachans
- Codex: Eldar & Codex: Craftworld Eldar
- Codex: Necrons
- Codex: Dark Angels
- Codex: Dark Eldar

Trial Rules
- Trial Assault rules
- Trial Vehicle rules
- Minor Psyker Powers

Name: Knights Club: The Alliance of Dragons
Description:
Previously, you met King Orc, whose daughter is missing. On the advice of his most loyal friend, the Prince of Nekashu, the King has entrusted you with a mission of the utmost importance: to bring his child back safe and sound by pulling her out of the clutches of the terrible mountain scoundrels....

Chevaliers 4 is a comic combined with a game, one title in a series subtitled "The comic in which you are the hero". You embody a character in a immersive story in which your choices guide your progress. You have a character sheet akin to those used in role-playing games that tracks your possessions, your special abilities, your coins, and your victory points. In general, gameplay consists in following the comic's panels — which contain clues, riddles and traps — and making choices about where to go and what to do, while using your visual perception to collect clues and be smart enough to resolve the riddles.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fluxx: Twist Gaming Promo Cards
Description:
is a New promo pack for Fluxx. It was offered as a reward to certain tiers in the "Twist Gaming Kickstarter - Year 4" campaign.
The pack contains 8 new cards to add to the game.

Name: Respect
Description:
Here you will find the worst criminals, thieves and scammers in the country. You must make a hole in the prison, earning the respect of the rest. It will not be easy, but not impossible!

Take advantage of the special abilities you have, complete missions, learn to defend yourself, win battles against other prisoners, buy your protection, get involved in the mafia, manage your money well and get to be the master of "LA PERLA" no matter what.

Players will become prisoners, seeking the utmost respect, taking on the role of Mario El Fuerte, Moe El Soplón, Harry El Loco, Jack El Carterista, Mr. White El Estafador and Qiang El Yakuza.

The player who gets 15 respect points wins.

Name: Tower Chess
Description:
Tower Chess is a chess variant that's played on a 6x6 grid with two fewer pawns on each side, without knights, and with all of the pieces being flat tokens rather than three-dimensional pieces.

Aside from the size of the game board, the main twist in the design is that rather than pieces being removed from the board, they are stacked. When a piece is moved, only the topmost piece of a stack is moved. Pieces that were once covered can move again once all the pieces that were on top have left. You may "capture" your own pieces by landing atop them.

As usual, the player to first capture the opponent's king — in this case, by placing one of their pieces atop it — wins.

Name: The Curious Stairs of Mr. Hincks
Description:
The Curious Stairs of Mr. Hincks is an escape room in a box prequel to The Curious Elevator of Mr. Hincks that is a standalone challenge.

Players will be solving puzzles on their way up to Mr. Hincks. You'll be using a website to check answers but hints are available if you get stuck.

Name: The Lord of the Rings: Journeys in Middle-earth – Dwellers in Darkness Figure Pack
Description:
Whether you are tackling the new challenges of Haunting of Dale or reexploring the trials of the Shadowed Paths campaign, you will face off against powerful villains, such as the Supplicant of Morgoth and Ollie the Troll. With the Dwellers in Darkness Figure Pack, you can bring those villains to life with new premium figures, along with one for the mysterious and sinister shade featured in Haunting of Dale.

Against such powerful foes, the party will need to be extra prepared. Fortunately, Dwellers in Darkness also includes a fresh batch of gear, including an additional copy of the Knife item (and new upgrades for it) and a brand-new trinket in the form of the Silver Circlet. Combine these useful tools with three new titles—such as Undying—and your party should be more than prepared to tackle the challenges presented by the darkness.

—description from the publisher

Name: Katz und Maus
Description:
Katz und Maus was published as a supplement to Auerbach's Deutschem Kinder-Kalender für 1913.

Up to 10 players play the mice and one player plays the cat. Te mice have to get from space 1 to space 64 without getting caught by the cat. If the cat and a mouse get on the same space, the mouse gets eaten and is out of play. If a player rolls more than he needs to reach space 64, he has to move the surplus points backwards.

Movement is determined by 2 dice (only 1 die from space 60 onward). Only the mice may use the diagonal lines, the cat has to go around. If the cat gets on an unnumbered intersection near the image of a cat, it needs to roll doublets to move again or has to pay 3 coins in it's  third next turn. If a mouse gets near a hiding hole it may chose to stop there with it's last moving point, to be safe from the cat.

If the cat rolls a doublet, it may move backwards to catch a mouse. If a mouse rolls a doublet or reaches a space with the image of a mouse, it's roll counts double.

If the cat gets to space 64 before any mouse it wins the game and the whole stake. If a mouse reaches space 64 the cat may only move up to space 63 and wait there for the remaining mice.

The players pay a stake of 2 coins for each mouse and the same amount of coins for the cat. If the cat passes a mouse the mouse has to pay 1 coin to the cat and vice versa.  If several mice use the same hiding hole, each has to pay 1 coin to the first mouse.

When there isn't any mouse remaining in play, the mice in space 64 and the cat share the stake.

—description from the publisher

Name: GYÜMI GÉNIUSZ: Smoothie promo
Description:
Shuffle the Smoothie promo cards into the base Gyumi Genius deck then prepare it as it’s written in the game rules.

When a player draws a Smoothie card in their own round it’s not obligatory to keep it! From now on you can collect different fruits and numbers for more points.

If the cards and numbers are duplicated you will get - 11 points.

—description from designer

Name: Recipe Roundup
Description:
Recipe Roundup is a card game whose purpose is to learn about the ingredients that make up delicious, healthy meals. Chefs collect the necessary ingredients to complete the perfect recipes. Ingredients are limited so the competition can be dicey. Chefs can strategically stock ingredients in their pantry, while others are left for their friends to “borrow”. If another Chef poaches your key ingredient, you’ll have to scramble or you’ll be in hot water. Chefs can expand their palette with new recipes, but beware of holding too many ingredients or you’ll be left holding the bag (of wasted food).

Players score points for completed Recipes and lose points for anything unused. Each Ingredient and Recipe is assigned a point value (top right corner of the card) based on the rarity of the required Ingredients, as well as the demand for those Ingredients in the Recipes. Collected Ingredients that aren’t made into a Recipe are wasted in the players’ Kitchens. Points for wasted Ingredients are subtracted: wasting food is bad! The player with the most points at the end of the round (or several rounds) wins.

-description from publisher

Name: Every Journey Begins on a Road: A Five Leagues From the Borderlands Expansion pack
Description:
This expansion pack for Five Leagues From the Borderlands is usable with any campaign and adds a new "roadside" encounter table.

This can be integrated into any campaign to add more variety, offering some low-intensity encounters against spiders, bandits and wandering fanatics.

This also means not every encounter you have is intrinsically tied to a Threat, making the game feel more alive and organic.

Additionally the pack also gives you a new tutorial sequence for starting a campaign, letting a new warband gain some experience and ease into the game before facing the full might of the Borderlands.

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Five Leagues From the Borderland

Name: Cohorts: Battles of Imperial Rome
Description:
Cohorts is a wargame system to land battles in Imperial Rome on 6mm to 20mm scale. 
The basic fighting unit is a Century (Rome) and a Unit (Gauls, Germans, and Britons). 
These are grouped into Cohorts and Bands.

Turns are performed by alternate activation.

Basic unit types are: infantry, cavalry, artillery (Scorpion), and special units (Nobles, Skirmishers, Chariots, Fanatics).

The objective is to provide an easy, agile, and adaptable rules system for the simulation of combat in the historical period between 200 BC and 200 AD, especially the period of Roman conquests over central Europe and Brittany. The main temporal focus is the Gallic Wars.

The definitions of a range of weapons were based on historical sources and serious publications. Likewise, the rules for combat formations and the historical characteristics of each army were also the target of research in specialized bibliography on the subject.

—description from the publisher

Name: Global Crisis: A Cooperative Game of Future Earth
Description:
Overview
GLOBAL CRISIS blends cooperative game play with elements of hidden role games. Your leadership represents a major world superpower and a collective of nations. Can you overcome ancient challenges and bring about world peace? Global Crisis is a collaborative game (with a twist) where everyone is working to stabilize global chaos. The twist is that one player might be an agent of chaos. Yes, might. This potential saboteur raises suspicion and increases the challenge. Trust will have to be earned, hopefully before it is too late!

Game Play
If players collectively score enough points, they win. Players score by passing as many global policies as possible (before time runs out) to address the five overarching sets of Global Challenges. If a player is the "Agent of Chaos," that player can only win if the group scores in the lowest bracket possible—thus causing all other players to collectively lose.

This game can be played with 2 to 5 players. All players begin with five cards. In the initial rounds, players gather as much information as they can about the cards in the hands of other players. Next, they will aid each other to remove challenge cards from their hands, organize them by sets (color), and finally try to score on each set. There are five sets of challenges that can score. Scoring is based on how many cards within a set the group can collect and whether the group can form a unique policy on each set—all before time runs out. Time expires when the players have formed a policy for all five sets of challenges, or when a player attempts to draw a card from the deck, but the deck has run out.

Theme
Global Crisis::, Earth 2265, the world is on the edge of total annihilation. Natural, social, political, military, and corporate forces have pushed humanity to the brink. The words of a Persian mystic and prisoner who foresaw the future 400 years prior stands truer than ever before...

"O ye the elected representatives of the people in every land! Take ye counsel together, and let your concern be only for that which profiteth mankind, and bettereth the condition thereof . . . Regard the world as the human body which, though at its creation whole and perfect, hath been afflicted, through various causes, with grave disorders and maladies. Not for one day did it gain ease, nay its sickness waxed more severe, as it fell under the treatment of ignorant physicians . . ." —Bahá'u'lláh

In fits and starts the process of creating global stability has been emerging for eons. Now the world faces it's most dire hour. The super-science of catastrophic weaponry, imbalanced and exploited globalization, and the unlocked potentials of Mother Nature's wrath have all given rise to myriad horrific problems which require a host of powerful solutions.

Forces of light and dark battle openly in public discourse, secretly behind the closed doors of the powerful elite, and deep within the minds and hearts of all people. Despite those who cling to a world long gone, a consensus has formed among the world's peoples and great leaders: a new world must be made. Led by the charge of reason and fueled by a desperate hope, a rallying cry for peace is heard:

"The Great Peace towards which people of goodwill throughout the centuries have inclined their hearts, of which seers and poets for countless generations have expressed their vision, and for which from age to age the sacred scriptures of mankind have constantly held the promise, is now at long last within the reach of the nations."   —From "The Promise of World Peace" by The Universal House of Justice

Is it too late to counteract eons of destruction? Can humanity set aside their petty squabbles, age old hatreds, and demagogue-stoked fears in order to bring about what is only dreamed of? And what of suspicions? Is everyone a trusted ally or do some lurk in shadow, attempting to plunge the world into a dark age of fallout and waste?

You are the rulers and leaders who will settle the fate of the world, for better or worse!

—description from the designer

Name: Black Seas: Bomb Ketch Squadron
Description:
A bomb ketch’s primary armament was not cannon or carronade, but a mortar mounted near the bow elevated at a high angle, that employed explosive shells rather than solid shot. They were designed primarily as bombardment vessels (hence the name bomb ketch), and were deployed against fixed land positions.

Though the British first employed a bomb vessel in 1347, it was the French who would develop a design (in the late 17th century) closer to those seen in the Age of Sail. The British copied and refined those designs over the next century, which led to two-masted ketches. Further development over the age of sail would result in bomb vessels designed as full-rigged ships (with three masts) – which allowed them to function as escort sloops between battles.

A bomb ketch is treated as a small vessel in Black Seas with a mortar mounted on the bow. It functions similarly to a gunboat, but benefits from greater speed and durability.

—description from the publisher's website

Name: Amfitryon
Description:
A trivia game about food, wine and etiquette.

The gameplay is similar to Trivial Pursuit, you roll a die to move, and pick up question cards. From the card, you're posed an easy (A) or difficult (B) question in one of three categories (food, wine or etiquette). Answer the question correctly, and you get to roll the die and move again.

When landing on a corner tile, you'll need to answer both the A and the B questions on the card correctly. If you do, you'll earn a special "diploma card". The first person to get three diploma cards wins the game.

Name: Refighting History: Volume 3 – The War of the Austrian Succession: Hohenfriedberg, Soor and Rocoux
Description:
Volume Three of Refighting History follows on from Volume Two continuing to examine and refight the battles of the War of the Austrian Succession. 
There are two more of Frederick’s big battles. 
These are Hohenfriedberg and Soor, each divided into two games. 
There is in addition a rather unusual game featuring the attack on Frederick’s camp by Nádasdy and Trenck during the battle of Soor.

However, the War of the Austrian Succession involved other armies and theatres of operations. Having covered Hohenfriedberg and Soor in this volume the focus move to the western theatre to cover the Rocoux. Here the French forces of Marshal Saxe face the Allied Army including Britain.

In addition to these battles, six games in all, there is the usual update on Charles’ wargame armies and some additional thoughts on artillery.

—description from designer
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: Ceramus
Description:
In Ceramus you are an important artist who will have to compete with others to become the best of all! Create amazing murals with different styles from different moments in the history of tiles. From Medieval to Islamic, from Art Nouveau to Portuguese.
Here, you will have to manage your tiles, use creativity and strategy to build your mural with the best combinations.
Ceramus is an abstract game inspired by tile art and features a mix of strategy and area domination and resource management.

Name: JailBird
Description:
JailBird is a bird-themed party card game where the main objective is for you to be the last bird standing, leaving all your avian accomplices in the custody of the Bird Police while you fly free.

You and your bird friends have committed heinous crimes, but not very well. In the deck of cards are evidence cards which prove you have committed these crimes. Use action cards to get rid of evidence cards in your hand.

Get rid of them now, because once someone draws a Bird Police card, all hell breaks loose! When that happens, a police raid takes place. The person with the most evidence at the end of the raid is sent to jail and is out of the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition): Starter Set
Description:
Warhammer 40,000 3rd Edition Box Set was a starter set for the 3rd Edition of Warhammer 40,000 released in 1998.

The box set contained the rulebook but the rulebook was also available on its own.

Contents:
- Black Templars: 9 Space Marines, 1 Space Marine Sergeant, 1 Landspeeder
- Dark Eldar: 20 Kabalite Warriors
- Other: Scenery, 6 Dice, templates, Rulebook. Reference Sheets

Name: Clean Cut
Description:
Clean Cut has 2 decks of 6 cards (the same set of 6 for each player), and those cards are used to construct a small time track. The cards quickly cycle back into the players' hands, with most of the game spent holding 4 cards.

The timing of card effects is based on the orientation of the cards, using markings on them to determine the order in which they take effect. Every card has 2 options for how it can be played, with changes to the effect of the card alongside the change in timing. Matches play out fast, because it can potentially only take 2 hits to land a "clean cut" and achieve victory.

—description from the designer

Name: Können Taxis fliegen?
Description:
Can taxis fly? NO!!!

Every child knows that, but it is not always that easy to correctly assess vehicles: Does a jumbo jet have an engine? How many wheels does a truck have? Do you need a driver's license to drive a motorized lawn mower?

Round after round you take a close look at one of 38 great planes, cars and ships. But it's not just a matter of knowledge, a quick reaction is also important.
But beware! If you attribute a wrong feature to a vehicle valuable points might go to another player.

Whoever has the most points after 5 rounds wins.

Based on the game principle of "Can pigs fly?" by Sonja Häßler.

—description from the designer

Name: Fly or Not
Description:
Can a bird fly? What about a bird tied with chains?? Or a bird tied with chains, with a jet-pack on its back, trapped in a cage which has balloon on top of it???

Fly or Not is an action/dexterity game in which players need to act quickly to grab the right answer to the question "whether the subject is flying or not?" from the table before anyone else can. On each turn players:
 
     Reveal a card; each round a card reveals which shows an animal that may fly or not!
     Roll dice; roll 1-3 dice based on the difficulty level which will affect the result.
     Grab the answer; if the result of "card+dice" flies, grab the "fly" marker (blue). If not, grab "not fly" marker (orange).
     Score points; Players may gain or lose points based on the marker they grabbed.


The first player to achieve a certain number of points (based on the number of players) wins!

—description from the designer

Name: Go Nuts for Donuts: Expansion Pack
Description:
How can you make Go Nuts for Donuts even more delicious? Add more donuts of course! In this Promo Pack there's a variety of delicious goodies that you can pick and choose to use with the base game to give the game more variety and fun!

—description from the publisher

Name: China: Europe
Description: Map of Europe made to fit the rules for China, rather than Web of Power. Can be downloaded from the designer's website.

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex Adeptus Astartes – Deathwatch
Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex Eldar – Harlequins
Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex Eldar – Craftworlds
Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Name: Alpha Steel
Description:
Out on the planet of Ibun, the Bots have created an advanced station. Here, the Bots must show their strength at the Alpha Steel Arena and decide who is the Last Bot Standing. The winner becomes the leader of the Elite Bot Army. The Age of the Human is over, the Age of the Bot begins! Go Droid!

In Alpha Steel, players control futuristic bots on the planet of Ibun. The goal is to defeat all other bots and remain the last player standing, inside the arena.

Everyone starts outside the arena with 1 rookie bot, 70,000 Azol (Azol- the currency in the game), 10 energy tokens, and 2 power cards. Each player starts with a rookie bot but can purchase a master bot during the game. On your turn, you will roll both dice.

From each dice you can: gain energy or 30,000 azol or attack other players’ bots. If you roll the same on both dice, you get double! For each attack you roll, your bot deals damage to other bots. The amount of damage you cause is written on your bot card. If you’re inside the arena, you attack everyone else. But if you’re outside the arena, you will only attack whoever is inside.

At the start, everyone is outside and the first player to roll an attack, enters the arena. All the other bots suffer damage. If you wish to leave the arena, you must wait till someone attacks you. Then, you pay the damage and exit. The player who had attacked you, must enter the arena.

If you stay in the arena for one whole round, you get 30,000 Azol after your dice roll. When you are inside, you can never gain health.

Power cards give your bots special strengths. you can play only one power card on your turn and must give it up after use. Some power cards can be played anytime. At no point can you have more than 2 power cards with you. Each power card has cost price and a profit or loss percentage mentioned in them. So, when you sell a card you do so either at a profit or a loss. All power cards sell at 50% loss, while all rookie bots sell at 50% profit. You can buy only one power card or a bot at the end of your turn. But, if you are inside the arena, you can buy a power card or bot anytime. If another player attacks you and you cannot pay Azol, you can sell your power card to get azol, otherwise you are eliminated. If you ever run out of energy tokens, you are eliminated!

When only two players remain in the game, it is the final duel. Both their bots enter the arena. You cannot buy any power cards or bots. you also cannot get energy or azol from dice.However, you can use the power cards you already have. The duel continues till a player is eliminated.

A round of play:
Your turn begins by rolling both dice. Then, you can play your power card. Other players cannot play a power card unless it is a play anytime card. Now, resolve the dice roll. remember if you are inside, you attack everyone. if you are outside, you only attack the person inside. Next, you can buy a power card or a bot. the player inside can buy anytime, other players can buy only on their turn. If the player inside wants to exit, they must do it now. If they exit, you must enter the arena. A player cannot exit if you did not roll an attack. Your turn ends.

Alpha Steel is a strategy based board game that is perfect for all ages. Whether it’s game night with friends, weekends with family or to combine the power of learning and play for kids, the board game provides an awesome experience for all. Enjoy as you use your robot’s special powers and tactics to vanquish other bots and lead the entire bot army.

-description from publisher

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex Adeptus Astartes – Blood Angels
Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex Adeptus Astartes – Space Marines
Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.

Description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.
